bioghist.head: Biographical / Historical
bioghist.p: The Lawrence Textile Strike, also known as the Bread and Roses strike, took place between the months of January and March 1912 and was led by the Industrial Workers of the World (IWW). In January 1st of that year, a Massachusetts law went into effect cutting female mill workers work week from 56 to 54 hours, effectively giving them a two-hour pay cut. Shortly after, workers learned that in addition to their cut in hours, they would also receive a cut in wages.

The strikers included immigrants from over 50 countries and a large number of women, the primary workforce in the textile industry. Police were brought in to quell the strikers and in January 1912, a striker Anna LoPizzo was killed during a protest - both sides blaming the other for her death. Two IWW strike leaders, Joseph Ettor and Arturo Giovannitti were arrested on charges of being accessories to murder, dispite being at a different location at the time. After this, IWW organizers Bill Haywood and Elizabeth Gurley Flynn came to Lawrence to head up the strikers.

After the death of Anna LoPizzo, martial law was declared but the violence between the police and the strikers continued. This led to the tactic of sending hundreds of strikers' children to families in New York, New Jersey, and Vermont in order to avoid the violence â€“ a move that drew national attention and sympathy for the striking workers. As the strike went on, congressional hearings would publicly reveal the unsafe working conditions in Lawrence mills and lead to calls to investigate the powerful companies such as the American Woolen Company that controlled much of the textile manufacturing in New England.

By March, mill owners agreed to a 20 percent raise throughout New England. The win was short lived however, as the IWW quickly lost its influence to other unions and many of the mill owners would eventually move operations to the Southern United States where there were fewer unionized shops.

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Photographs showing the end of the Lawrence Textile Strike, also known as the Bread and Roses strike, on March 14, 1912, Lawrence, Massachusetts, striking workers, Big Bill Haywood speaking, strikers' children returning to Lawrence, and Decoration Day (Memorial Day).

did.unittitle: Various photos after strike: parades, meeting on common, Decoration Day
Mass meeting, Lawrence Common, calling off strike, ATHM# 1993.131.17

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Snapshot gelatin silver print. Image depicts a meeting on Lawrence Common, Lawrence, Mass., where the textile strike was called off. View shows men, women and children standing on Common, listening to IWW leader speaking from grandstand. Written on reverse: Mass Meeting Common March 14, 1912 Calling off strike."

did.unittitle: Leading the parade when children came home, ATHM# 1993.131.18

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Snapshot gelatin silver print, [1912]. Image depicts two little girls, holding flower baskets, leading a group of Ayer Mill Spinning Room workers in the parade celebrating the return of children of strikers who had been removed from Lawrence, Mass., during the textile strike of 1912. Written on reverse: "Leading the parade when kiddies came home."

did.unittitle: At railroad station waiting for children to come home, ATHM# 1993.131.19

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Snapshot gelatin silver print. Image depicts crowd at B&M (Boston & Maine) railroad station, waiting for the return of children of strikers who had been removed from Lawrence, Mass., during the textile strike of 1912. Written on reverse: "At B & M. station waiting for kiddies to come home."

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Snapshot gelatin silver print. Image depicts parade through Lawrence, Mass., on Decoration Day (now known as Memorial Day) in 1912, two months after textile strike was over. Written on reverse: "I.W.W. parade Decoration Day 1912."

did.unittitle: Parade for children coming home to Lawrence, ATHM# 1993.131.21

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Snapshot gelatin silver print. Image depicts parade through Lawrence, Mass., when children of strikers who had been removed from Lawrence during the textile strike returned home. Visible are crowds of onlookers; several horse-drawn wagons containing children; band. Written on reverse: "When "kiddies" came home."

did.unittitle: Leaving mass meeting on Lawrence Common, ATHM# 1993.131.22

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: March 14, 1912. Snapshot gelatin silver print. Image depicts people leaving the mass meeting on Lawrence Common, Lawrence, Mass., on March 14, 1912, after the textile strike was declared off. Written on reverse: "Leaving Mass Meeting Common March 14, 1912 Strike declared off."

did.unittitle: Grave of Ramy, Decoration Day, ATHM# 1993.131.23

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Snapshot gelatin silver prin. Image depicts large crowd at grave of boy apparently killed or who died during textile strike, with several people laying wreaths. Decoration Day now known as Memorial Day. Written on reverse: "Grave of 'Ramy' boy Decoration Day 1912."

did.unittitle: Grave of Annie LoPizzo, Decoration Day, ATHM# 1993.131.24

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: Snapshot gelatin silver print. Image depicts a crowd of people laying a wreath on the grave of Anna LoPizzo (name variously spelled as: LoPezza, Lopezza, Lopezzo) on Decoration Day (now known as Memorial Day). LoPizzo was shot and killed on January 29, 1912 while protesting during the textile strike in Lawrence, Mass. Written on reverse: "Grave of Annie La Piza? Decoration Day 1912."

did.unittitle: Big Bill Haywood on Lawrence Common, ATHM# 1993.131.25

scopecontent.head: Scope and Contents
scopecontent.p: March 14, 1912. Snapshot gelatin silver print. Image depicts William "Big Bill" Haywood of the I.W.W. speaking on Lawrence Common, Lawrence, Mass., March 14, 1912, when the textile strike was called off. Written on reverse: " 'Big Bill' in action March 14, 1912."
